Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV0021 - 3D spatial information for Sustainable Urbanism","description":"

Sustainable Urbanism is a way of designing and building cities to ensure long term viability and liveability. It
requires collaboration and cooperation of many disciplines as well as the understanding and use of state-of-the
art geospatial technologies. The course will provide a unique study environment in which the students will gain
critical knowledge on 3D geospatial technologies, which will be further applied in collaborative multidisciplinary
design and management of real-wold projects guided by experts in the field. The aims to strengthen the cross
disciplinary still of the students and make them highly competitive on the national and international sustainable
development problems.

Individual assessment, which will consist of two components: 1) (moderated) peer-review of team members (10%), 2) written report  and reflection on the completed project (10%)

contentlets.description:
Sustainable Urbanism is a way of designing and building cities to ensure long term viability and liveability. It
requires collaboration and cooperation of many disciplines as well as the understanding and use of state-of-the
art geospatial technologies. The course will provide a unique study environment in which the students will gain
critical knowledge on 3D geospatial technologies, which will be further applied in collaborative multidisciplinary
design and management of real-wold projects guided by experts in the field. The aims to strengthen the cross
disciplinary still of the students and make them highly competitive on the national and international sustainable
development problems.
contentlets.title: 3D spatial information for Sustainable Urbanism

Communication in the Built Environment","description":"

This course will give you the communication strategies and techniques to both create and share design ideas and concepts with others. You will be introduced to the different communication techniques that are used throughout the design process from conceptual design to project completion. You will learn how communication conventions and strategies vary depending on what is being communicated, for what purpose and at what stage the project is at. This course will introduce you to visual, spatial and oral modes of communicating design ideas in the Built Environment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a63b0298dbf61010358b403c3a9619b9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Developing your Style","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment builds on the previous assessment by using the collected data from students allocated site and asks students to synthesize principles and processes introduced in class and lectures to communicate specific concepts or ideas. The deliverables include digital drawings and 3D models.
Assessment Criteria (weighting in brackets):
• Distinctive and skilful application of digital and analogue techniques (50%)
• Appropriate selection and adherence to conventions and standards (30%)
• Creative representation of your discipline (20%)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6e2d8e98dbf61010358b403c3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c25d0ad8dbf61010358b403c3a9619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cbac8e98dbf61010358b403c3a9619c4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb3d8e98dbf61010358b403c3a9619d2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"38dec61cdbf61010358b403c3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Tracing the City","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment will investigate, map and document a location. Students will work to produce a record of elements of the location. This will include images, plans, maps and relelvant data.
Assessment Criteria (weighting in brackets):
• Skilful application of digital and analogue techniques (50%)
• Appropriate selection and adherence to conventions and standards (30%)
• Range of elements mapped and or documented (20%)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6e2d8e98dbf61010358b403c3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"eb3d8e98dbf61010358b403c3a9619d2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"58ae021cdbf61010358b403c3a961964","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Communication Process Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is a record of your design communication process work during the course.You will upload images of your process work at the end of each tutorial and write a reflection on your learning. Each tutorial post should include a minimum of 3 images and 100 words.
Assessment Criteria (weighting in brackets):
• evidence of learning insights 30%
• evidence of effective written and visual communication 40%
• evidenceof design consideration in presentation format 30%

This course introduces students to Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication, with emphasis on the direct
relationship between Mathematics and Geometry, and how these two fields constitute the foundations of
any parametric design process.
Students will progressively gain skills in the creation of adaptable models using Grasshopper and will be
able to explore the advantages of a flexible design compared with a rigid model done in Rhinoceros. The
connection between the software and the plugin will be explained in depth, demonstrating that an efficient
combination of both usually leads to a more effective solution.
The rationalisation of complex geometries for fabrication is essential for the manufacture of objects,
installations, façades and structures, and must be taken into account from the conceptual design and 3D
modelling stage to project documentation.
Based on the concepts learned in the lectures and through the development of the proposed collection of
exercises in the tutorials, students will learn how to transform a complex surface into a series of buildable
and connectable elements. The digital models will be then translated into physical prototypes, allowing the
students to evaluate their designs empirically, exploring and working with different digital fabrication
techniques, construction systems, and materials.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,parametric design,digital fabrication,3d modelling,rhinoceros,grasshopper,scripting
contentlets.description:
This course introduces students to Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication, with emphasis on the direct
relationship between Mathematics and Geometry, and how these two fields constitute the foundations of
any parametric design process.
Students will progressively gain skills in the creation of adaptable models using Grasshopper and will be
able to explore the advantages of a flexible design compared with a rigid model done in Rhinoceros. The
connection between the software and the plugin will be explained in depth, demonstrating that an efficient
combination of both usually leads to a more effective solution.
The rationalisation of complex geometries for fabrication is essential for the manufacture of objects,
installations, façades and structures, and must be taken into account from the conceptual design and 3D
modelling stage to project documentation.
Based on the concepts learned in the lectures and through the development of the proposed collection of
exercises in the tutorials, students will learn how to transform a complex surface into a series of buildable
and connectable elements. The digital models will be then translated into physical prototypes, allowing the
students to evaluate their designs empirically, exploring and working with different digital fabrication
techniques, construction systems, and materials.
contentlets.title: Parametric Design and Digital Fabrication

History of Design Thinking","description":"

This course on the history of design thinking explores connections between the disciplines of architecture, interior architecture and industrial design. We will take into consideration current practice, particularly perceived problems, such as the alienating nature of many recent design projects. These prompt an inquiry into past principles that demand our attention now. Historical achievements are reinterpreted, with the aim of stimulating alternative design strategies.


The ancient Greeks and Romans are discussed, because their writings influenced designers in later epochs. A tradition of thinking about design stressed the significance of topics, such as order, proportion, analogy, symmetry, decorum, economy, ornament, the profile of mouldings, the angle of view, rhythmic measure, empathy, memory, monumentality and the play of light.


Emphasis is placed on the analogy between a person and a design. This involves the theory of a human being as a ‘type’, whose constitution accords with built forms. Analysis of this accentuates human characteristics and actions, which are associated with privileged forms. The history of design thinking offers insight into a human being, who feels an affinity with a city, street, building and room, as well as the fundamental elements of a column, door, window, ornament, chair and door handle.

It integrates a variety of digital media and employs creative ideas and techniques to effectively communicate a chosen topic.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9667c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2a - Multimedia Presentation Development (Process)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

As a lead up to the major presentation (assignment 2b), students are required to construct a ‘preview’ to their final work. This assignment must embody the narrative they are using for their presentation.

The assignment must include a storyboard and mood board as well as an explanation of the idea and message of the presentation.

Feedback Process
Immediately after submitting, students will peer review each other in relation to the assessment criteria. This process will be fully public to all in the class allowing everyone to see the feedback of others. The peer review will be completed within a week. At this point, tutors will post their feedback to the same location, once again allowing feedback for one group to be used as learning for others.

An assessment criteria rubric will also provide general feedback on standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0267c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8667c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c267c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3967c537db791c50eb6b147a3a96196d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2b - Multimedia Design Presentation (Product)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

The major project for the course is a multimedia presentation that fulfils the following requirements.

  • The presentation must be designed around some unifying theme/narrative that is clearly evident to the viewer and facilitates the appreciation of the story being told.
  • The presentation must be interactive - the viewer/user must have some control over the sequence or flow of the presentation.
  • The presentation should make use of as many kinds of media as possible, but skilfully interwoven using the facilities of the employed software.
  • The presentation should have a clear, focused message, providing the audience with insight and understanding of the subject that is presented.

Feedback Process
Within 10 days, students will receive their grade with comments on how they performed.

An assessment criteria rubric will also provide general feedback on standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0267c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4e67c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8667c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c267c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7167c537db791c50eb6b147a3a961972","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3 - Critical Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The critical reflection covers what was learned, including the processes and outcomes of the course topics and experiences. It should include a self-assessment and ways the student's skills and knowledge could be applied in the future to course work and in their profession.

The reflection will be graded in stages, part a (10%) in early term, part b (15%) at the end of term.

Feedback Process
Within 10 days, students will receive their grade with comments on how they performed. This will include annotations on their written document.

An assessment criteria rubric will also provide general feedback on standards.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8a67c537db791c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b967c537db791c50eb6b147a3a961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 - Interactive Web Animation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Production of a short (no longer than 30 second), interactive animation for the web, using 2D animation principles discussed.

Feedback Process
Within 10 days, students will be given online feedback. This will include how well they did in relation to all the assessment criteria (written comments) as well as identifying their position on a scale from FL to HD for each criterion.

General feedback to all includes a rubric showing what is expected at each level of the assessment criteria.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,multimedia design
contentlets.description: The course develops skills in effective digital communication and explores the potential of multimedia as a design presentation tool. Through the use of software for digital media creation, manipulation and multimedia authoring, students create a short, interactive web animation and a comprehensive multimedia presentation. The presentation represents the culmination of skills and knowledge through the course. It integrates a variety of digital media and employs creative ideas and techniques to effectively communicate a chosen topic.
contentlets.title: Multimedia in Design Presentation

contentlets.description: This course develops an understanding of solar efficient architecture and builds on this to develop skills in energy performance simulation.  House energy performance rating is fast becoming an essential requirement for building applications and this requires specific skills. It targets core areas of efficiency in space heating and cooling and lighting design. Material is presented as lectures and seminars, supplemented with readings.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2000 - Re-enchanting the City: Designing the Human Habitat","description":"

This course is an introduction to the interdisciplinary nature of city making that focuses on a cutting-edge, high-density urban infill project, Central Park, Sydney as its case study. The case study is used to explore the interdependencies of the professions at play; urban design, architecture, construction management, city planning, landscape architecture, interior architecture and industrial design. The entire development process for the urban infill project is investigated, from the earliest planning and site purchases through to completion, and from the broad contextual scale through to the design intricacies. This includes design innovations in green technologies, structure, construction, environmental and building service, framing within the wider context of infrastructure, governance and the political economy. A key question investigated in this course is: how do we engage local democracy to make urban density both sustainable and poetic in current global cities?

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2001 - Emerging Digital Technologies","description":"

Students in this course will gain knowledge in the technical and operational principles of emerging digital technologies and identify applications of emerging digital technologies in and for the design of the built environment. This course will give students the opportunity to familiarise themselves with two emerging digital technologies that can be chosen out of a pool of four different technologies.


At present, the course offers the following four skills trajectories: ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION; ROBOTICS; GAMING; AR&VR. Students need to choose TWO out of the four prior to their enrolment. Possible combinations are:


·        ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION / ROBOTICS (Strong fabrication focus)


·        GAMING / AR&VR (Strong synthetic environments focus)


·        ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION / AR&VR (Mixed focus leaning to Processes in Construction)


·        GAMING / ROBOTICS (Mixed focus leaning to Human / Machine Interaction)


At the end of the course students can demonstrate skills in operating emerging digital technologies and apply emerging digital technologies in their own design projects and professional work.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,advanced digital fabrication,robotics,gaming,augmented reality,visual reality
contentlets.description:
Students in this course will gain knowledge in the technical and operational principles of emerging digital technologies and identify applications of emerging digital technologies in and for the design of the built environment. This course will give students the opportunity to familiarise themselves with two emerging digital technologies that can be chosen out of a pool of four different technologies.

At present, the course offers the following four skills trajectories: ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION; ROBOTICS; GAMING; AR&VR. Students need to choose TWO out of the four prior to their enrolment. Possible combinations are:

·        ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION / ROBOTICS (Strong fabrication focus)

·        GAMING / AR&VR (Strong synthetic environments focus)

·        ADVANCED DIGITAL FABRICATION / AR&VR (Mixed focus leaning to Processes in Construction)

·        GAMING / ROBOTICS (Mixed focus leaning to Human / Machine Interaction)

At the end of the course students can demonstrate skills in operating emerging digital technologies and apply emerging digital technologies in their own design projects and professional work.
contentlets.title: Emerging Digital Technologies

This course centres on understanding holistic concepts such as wellbeing, restoration, social inclusion and health and their implications for design of the built environment. The outdoor environment is the focus of the course, specifically the implications for design in a range of settings, including hospitals, schools, parks, public and recreational spaces; for the population as a whole and for a range of specific population groups including children and youth, the elderly and people with disabilities.

This course will challenge students' thinking about planning, designing and creating environments for children and young people. The course content will introduce students to how designers and planners can strive to meet the needs of children and young people in urban environments. It will introduce them to contemporary issues and relevant research methods in order to assist their understanding of how to accommodate children and young people's needs in specific settings such as neighbourhoods, schools, childcare environments, hospitals and youth centres. Students will demonstrate their understanding and enhance their professional practice through participating in workshops focused on the needs of children and young people.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2219 - History of Australian Landscape Design","description":"

This course traces the evolutionary development of significant periods in the history of landscape design in Australia by means of a chronological thread in the form of lectures and field excursions if applicable. The significant chronological periods are interwoven with themes of influence and events as well as identifying major personalities and works which have had an impact in forming the culture of landscape and the cultural landscape of Australia. It provides a framework for understanding the changing landscape resulting from the interaction of the indigenous place and imposed land uses and values by Euro-Australian occupation of the land. As such it serves as an introduction to the subject of designed and managed landscapes, particularly through the identification of known persons and places, and the extent of theories and influences regarding landscape design within the Australian context.

contentlets.description: This course traces the evolutionary development of significant periods in the history of landscape design in Australia by means of a chronological thread in the form of lectures and field excursions if applicable. The significant chronological periods are interwoven with themes of influence and events as well as identifying major personalities and works which have had an impact in forming the culture of landscape and the cultural landscape of Australia. It provides a framework for understanding the changing landscape resulting from the interaction of the indigenous place and imposed land uses and values by Euro-Australian occupation of the land. As such it serves as an introduction to the subject of designed and managed landscapes, particularly through the identification of known persons and places, and the extent of theories and influences regarding landscape design within the Australian context.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2220 - The Culture of Nature","description":"

This course explores the ways in which culture fosters specific ideas about "Nature." Particular attention is given to representation of ideas toward Nature in the arts and the built environment. The intent is to provide students with a framework for understanding and articulating the complex relationship between nature and culture, and a foundation for integrating this understanding into their own work as designers. Skills in critical thinking, essay writing, and discussion are extended and evaluated. The course considers a wide range of perspectives on the topic.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3b794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961967","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3: Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students  develop a comprehensive essay that synthesises  their knowledge and understanding of  a topic of their choice. Topics guided by essay questions provided in the assessment handout. Students receive feedback as annotated comments inside Turnitin with rubric marking guide for final submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ef794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961960","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"27794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Blog","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Students construct an individual blog by recording responses to weekly readings using text and visuals. Each entry between 200-500 words.  Preliminary feedback in Week 3 via discussion based peer review.  Analytical rubric used as a guide. Final submission in Week 10. 

Students will receive written feedback with comments by week 5.  

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2f794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a3794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"db794d7bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Essay proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

 

Students prepare a visual poster incorporating a 500-800 word proposal outlining chosen essay topic, key themes to be explored.

Students will present their poster and a 500-word associated blurb to the class.

 

Word Limit: 500

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2255 - Architecture in Sydney","description":"

The emphasis of the course is on the study and analysis of buildings through a series of site visits and tours of the city of Sydney. The aim is to familiarise students with the built history of Sydney, its important architectural landmarks and the pertinent issues relating to these landmarks. The course will cover pre-colonial inhabitation, colonial architecture, Victorian-era buildings, the tall buildings debate, and the modern, post-modern and contemporary city. The course will consist of lectures, class discussions and city tours, with written and illustrated assignment work.

Blogging is used to critically reflect on learning and demonstrate subject knowledge gained.

Each week you will be expected to think deeply about the material and activities and write a blog entry that identifies the insights/learning you have uncovered. The entry should relate to how you see a topic tying into your own work, research you have found, or any other insights you have developed.

Blogging will be graded in 4 stages, each worth 10%.

Feedback Process
General feedback to be provided weekly, with reference to the assessment rubric.

The aim of the first project is to develop knowledge and skills in real-time 3D at small scale. You will be expected to create a simple 3D object, which will be animated and interactive. The model you produce is set to be simple to limit the complexities. You can have a background image or a simple environment for the object, but the focus should be on the object itself.

It is expected that you will be creative with the way the 3D model is presented. Be imaginative with the object choice, animation and interactivity, so they all contribute to say something about the object.

Feedback Process
General feedback as well as student specific feedback provided witin 10 days following the submissions. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3dbb997bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fdbb997bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a5bb997bdb3d1c50eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Immersive Game A (group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The major assignment for the course is the production of an immersive, 3D game bringing together subject knowledge, creative and technical skills. In addition, it will include a document outlining the rationale, investigations and process.

Project objectives

  • Apply game theory and user experience design, including immersion, into a digital game experience.
  • Apply iterative design through agile methodology
  • Evaluate technologies from both theoretical and practical perspectives.
  • Critique and analyse game and digital products, including commercial games, student work
  • Develop and apply technical skills in the use of game and 3D technologies
  • Synthesise connections to built environment disciplines and your own career

Immersive Game A covers the process. It continues into Immersive Game B which is the end product.

Feedback Process
Weekly/fortnightly as project develops.
Final grade and feedback – within 10 days of submission.

contentlets.description: This course explores advanced multimedia technology and 3D game development and, in doing so, develops insight into applications for architectural and built environment contexts. It draws from the fields of digital media, computer science and game theory to find interdisciplinary relationships. 3D games are used as a vehicle to understand enhanced levels of digital communication, user engagement and 3D representation. The major project is a 3D game proposal, which develops an appreciation of issues in game design and communication of ideas, as well as the use of the latest tools and techniques in creating rich digital media experiences.
contentlets.title: Immersive Digital Environments

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BENV2708","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2708 - Interior Detailing","description":"

Design resolution, at a fine scale, highlights issues of quality and plays a central role in detailing to achieve buildings and interiors which are original and coherent examples of good design. The practice and technology of detailing interiors; seeks to enhance the designer's critical capacity when assessing options; extends their design vocabulary; explore concepts of the overall to the specific; and introduces planning strategies for detailing while still at an early stage of the design process. Tutorials will be based upon residential project work. Lectures will cover both the theoretical and practical definitions of 'detailing' as a language and will be supplemented by lectures covering current residential techniques of documentation and developing building contract documentation to support successful building outcomes. The program is fast paced and requires the production of a consistent documentation package. Completion of a resolved and consistent documentation package requires research, identification and resolution of design construction issues. To enable students to achieve the required level of documentation skill, within the semester, and experience current professional working processes, all course work will be done in groups. Students need to be able to establish a process and commitment, for group work.


Note: This Built Environment elective course is best suited to students with a practical use and understanding of CAD software plus the language of documentation (technical drawing skills including plans, sections and elevations).

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"15e94c0cdb21bc10fe4b322af49619e7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group Project B","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

contentlets.keywords: built environment,interior detailing,interior design
contentlets.description:
Design resolution, at a fine scale, highlights issues of quality and plays a central role in detailing to achieve buildings and interiors which are original and coherent examples of good design. The practice and technology of detailing interiors; seeks to enhance the designer's critical capacity when assessing options; extends their design vocabulary; explore concepts of the overall to the specific; and introduces planning strategies for detailing while still at an early stage of the design process. Tutorials will be based upon residential project work. Lectures will cover both the theoretical and practical definitions of 'detailing' as a language and will be supplemented by lectures covering current residential techniques of documentation and developing building contract documentation to support successful building outcomes. The program is fast paced and requires the production of a consistent documentation package. Completion of a resolved and consistent documentation package requires research, identification and resolution of design construction issues. To enable students to achieve the required level of documentation skill, within the semester, and experience current professional working processes, all course work will be done in groups. Students need to be able to establish a process and commitment, for group work.

Note: This Built Environment elective course is best suited to students with a practical use and understanding of CAD software plus the language of documentation (technical drawing skills including plans, sections and elevations).
contentlets.title: Interior Detailing

This course will introduce students and practitioners to issues related to planning, design and implementation of green roofs and green walls in urban environments. It will also deal with the related issues of high density living, design of urban infill, and the relationship between the built form, urban site, city context and the integration of constructed vegetated open space, for both contemporary and future uses. The course spans from feasibility, planning and urban design issues to construction and planting issues.  It uses the city built environment as a laboratory for developing design skills and knowledge in a holistic sense, including the design of technical and natural systems.

This subject provides an introductory understanding of the role of transport planning as a planning tool that can be used to achieve positive overall planning outcomes in the built urban environment. Students will gain an understanding of the need and role for transport planning in the planning, important concepts and analytical tools for planning of transport systems including public transport systems.

Working in teams you will prepare a detailed case study of a public transport project, with a focus on how transport planning theory and data analysis informed the project.  Submitted as a report and presentation.

\n

Feedback via rubric

This end-of-term test assesses your comprehension of key course concepts.

\n

Feedback via analytical rubric

This assignment involves lab work conducted in tutorial time. Feedback via marking sheet.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"73135d94dba9fc10fe4b322af4961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7b135d94dba9fc10fe4b322af4961937","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb135d94dba9fc10fe4b322af496193a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2 Individual Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Individual Essay (Essay 30%) - Transport planning must provide the information necessary for making decisions on when and where improvements should be made in the transport systems in keeping with community visions and goals. For this assignment, students will select and review a major transport planning document. The essay must document the plan, its background, future visions, goals & objectives, proposed strategies, performance measure,s and critical reviews. Marking criteria will be available. Feedback will be provided based on the marking criteria and a rubric.

contentlets.description: This subject provides an introductory understanding of the role of transport planning as a planning tool that can be used to achieve positive overall planning outcomes in the built urban environment. Students will gain an understanding of the need and role for transport planning in the planning, important concepts and analytical tools for planning of transport systems including public transport systems.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BENV2942","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV2942 - Rural Planning","description":"This course has been designed specifically to give students an appreciation of the issues associated with planning for rural areas, a vital component of land use management in Australia. Rural areas include the agricultural land, natural areas and urban settlements of regional Australia. It introduces students to a range of practical planning documents and instruments, including rural lands studies, rural strategies, Local Environmental Plans and Development Control Plans. Students will also learn about the various policy mechanisms used both in Australia and overseas. The course utilises fieldbased learning and usually involves a fieldtrip to a rural NSW location during which students undertake a rural planning exercise with practical application for a local council.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"30286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961948","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment No 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Assignment 3. Outline Local Strategic Planning Statement of a rural and regional LGA.

Students will be required to prepare and submit an outline Local Strategic Planning Statement on the local government area visited in the field trip. The outline LSPS will be a 20 year vision for the LGA addressing strategic land use, transport and infrastructure priorities, environmental management priorities and community needs and priorities. The document will also be required to address issues of resilience against natural hazards and climate change. The information for the assignment will come from the field trip as well as a review of relevant strategic planning documents and guidelines from the NSW Government. The format and scope of the outline LSPS will be discussed in class prior to the field trip. The assignment will be evaluated on the following:

• Breadth of coverage of the issue
• Various sources of information (e.g. Council and Government Reports, lectures, etc.)
• Use of diagrams and photos 

Weight: 40%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f4286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"20286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial discussion and engagement","assessment_type":{"label":"Performance","value":"performance"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students required to engage in a series of tutorial discussions at the end of the lecture. This tutorial discussion provides opportunity for students to verbally present thier understading and knowleage during the class by reflecting the selected rural and regional planning issues.   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f4286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment No 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Assignment 1. Written submission that identifies and summarises the key rural planning issues facing a local government area in regional NSW.

Students are to prepare a 1000 word written submission that identifies and summarises the key rural planning issues facing a local government area in regional NSW. The assignment will be based on the course topics covered in Weeks 1-4. Students will be required to identify a regional local government area and undertake research of that LGA based on local Council plans and strategies as well as relevant regional strategies prepared by the Department of Planning, Environment and Infrastructure.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"20286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961939","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9c286d7bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961921","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment No 2 (group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 2. Group Assignment addressing a land use conflict case study in rural and regional NSW.

Students are to take part in a group assignment addressing a land use conflict case study in rural and regional NSW. The group assignment will involve the preparation of a 2500 word written submission to a consent authority objecting to or in support of a development application for a development that has the potential to generate land use conflict. The selected development could be a real development or a hypothetical development. The submission will need to identify the land use conflict, address the strategic and statutory planning context of the proposed development and any other national, state, regional or local policy responses to the land use conflict issue. The submissions will then be presented by team members in a mock planning panel public meeting. The assignments will be evaluated on the following: • Range and appropriateness of issues addressed in the submission • Concise nature of the discussion and planning arguments put forward • Use of a wide range of sources of information • Use of correctly sourced diagrams and photos • Group presentation to the panel

Weight: 30% (20% report / 10% presentation)

contentlets.keywords: built environment,planning and urban development program,rural planning
contentlets.description: This course has been designed specifically to give students an appreciation of the issues associated with planning for rural areas, a vital component of land use management in Australia. Rural areas include the agricultural land, natural areas and urban settlements of regional Australia. It introduces students to a range of practical planning documents and instruments, including rural lands studies, rural strategies, Local Environmental Plans and Development Control Plans. Students will also learn about the various policy mechanisms used both in Australia and overseas. The course utilises fieldbased learning and usually involves a fieldtrip to a rural NSW location during which students undertake a rural planning exercise with practical application for a local council.
contentlets.title: Rural Planning

Research Methods in the Built Environment","description":"

This course provides an introduction to the research process, qualitative and quantitative research, mixed methods research, it also covers the basic techniques of survey design, data collection and analysis, introductory statistics, which are an integral component of a built environment graduate’s skill set.

Students will be introduced the fundamentals of research, which may include processes such as: formulation of research problem (question), research aim and objectives, review of previous studies and literature, formulation of research design, methods and data collection tools and techniques, methods of data analysis and interpretation and discussion of research findings. In addition, students will be introduced the research integrity, ethics consideration, and suitable referencing style. The aim of this course is to (ii) develop students’ skills in carrying out a scientific research project by the understanding of research methods in the built environment and (ii) to guide students to employ a range of research techniques through the process of identifying a suitable method of data collection, data analysis tools and techniques.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0596153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class Online Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Two online quizzes will assess students’ participation in before-class activities and in-class lectures. They are part of students’ assessment and they are collections of pre-class online MCQ tests. If students’ do the MCQ activities before each class and participate actively in lectures and tutorial sessions, they can expect to pass the two online quizzes in Week 3 and Week 10.The results and feedback will be provided to students immediately after quizzes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"0996153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3496153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3c96d13fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7096153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"bc96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961922","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f496153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f896153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6496d13fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data Analysis and Interpretation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are also required to practise their skills outside class time by analysing data in a group. A case-based assignment project will require students to conduct statistical analysis by using SPSS software for data relevant to the built environment context. Students need to interpret and discuss the results or outcomes of the analysis for supporting the developed hypotheses, research questions or propositions. They also need to record conclusions and recommendations in a report, and associate interpretations to justify your conclusions or recommendations. A self-directed learning approach will be used in this subject, with students having the flexibility to choose their own reading material and explore beyond the requirements of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"0996153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"f896153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6496d13fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

The research proposal assignment is designed to evaluate students understanding on the requirement and process of developing a detailed thesis proposal. For this assignment, students are required to undertake scholarly enquiry, locating, evaluating and using relevant information towards justifying their research questions; research aim and objectives; and proposed research method(s). A detailed thesis proposal needs to comprise a comprehensive review of the relevant literature.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV6713 - Architectural Spatialisation","description":"

This course is focused on the critical study of spatiality of the built environment through interpretive sketching and live architectural drawing. Theories of visual art and architecture inform an extended sequence of field studios at various sites around Sydney Harbour. Field studios are supported by occasional lectures, individual guidance, collaborative exercises, peer review, group discussions and a significant student-led public exhibition.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,architectural space,free-hand drawing,interpretation,conceptualisation
contentlets.description: This course is focused on the critical study of spatiality of the built environment through interpretive sketching and live architectural drawing. Theories of visual art and architecture inform an extended sequence of field studios at various sites around Sydney Harbour. Field studios are supported by occasional lectures, individual guidance, collaborative exercises, peer review, group discussions and a significant student-led public exhibition.
contentlets.title: Architectural Spatialisation

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV6800 - Professional Placement","description":"

The Professional Placement provides Built Environment students an opportunity to gain targeted professional work experience, and to explore the dynamics, requirements and expectations of a built environment workplace. The placement provides opportunities for students to develop practical knowledge, capabilities and employability skills within a supervised and immersive setting. Students spend 140 hours working with a host organisation on a placement or project basis. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"36b0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

For most students this is an enjoyable paper to complete. It is made easier by adding some notes each week to a journal on what the student observes, is surprised by, as well as challenging moments or tasks, and highlights that help show that the intern is progressing with skills and / or knowledge of their industry, It is recommended to read an article or two on " internships" early on in the internship (there are many) to gain some insight into the joys and challenges that can be experienced in an internship. It may give students confidence to tackle a challenge early on ( e.g. being given repetitive tasks, or not receiving enough feedback on one's work). Students are expected to cite from two to three articles on internships, from several pieces of organizational literature, share good examples from this internship to support their comments and to include answers to the questions provided on Moodle. A bibliography is to be included with the articles that the student has cited from as well items from the leganto list that are used. Students are encouraged to draw on literature from their University studies. This paper can be structured as the student chooses e.g. into stages of the internship or using the suggested headings on Moodle. It is important that the student can indicate their progress on how they have they engaged with the literature and identify what learning they have achieved in areas such as the challenge of moving from the University setting to the workplace ( especially if it is their first internship), the impact of diversity around them and what ethical and social responsibilities are involved in their industry or area of specialty . Listing key skills and new knowledge gained can be linked to examples from the student's role and tasks undertaken.

Precursor to the organisational essay. 750 to 1000 words. Written feedback within 10 working days. Additional details: The student meets with the Academic Convenor after 2- 3 days of the internship ( or earlier if a Summer internship ) to discuss areas of interest for the topic for this essay summary ( and this topic is maintained for the organisational essay.) The topic is a statement or question that incorporates a few key aspects of organizational theory e.g. the structure, function , culture, leadership, communication, challenges etc that can be closely related to the student's intern tasks. Students can use an approach that incorporates e.g. an organizational perspective, management perspective, knowledge perspective or can look at some organizational models and test out if they are explain how their host organization functions. The structure of this paper will be clarified especially if students have not completed an essay summary before. Although a summary, it is to be written as an academic paper so not dot points. Students develop an argument, and identify how they plan to use relevant texts and articles ( see leganto for our texts and suggested literature) to support this. Suggested ideas are shared by the Convenor, as needed, and support by email and further meetings are provided. Two seminars are offered during the term for peer support, academic guidance and sharing of internship experience. It is crucial , as there are no weekly tutorials , that students start reading as early as they can, to acquaint themselves with aspects of organizational theory that interest them and are relevant to their host. Making links with the reading to one's host can be exciting and insightful. Students must reference this paper with at least five (5) articles in addition to the leganto list which means they need to source five or more relevant articles or chapters on their chosen topic.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"72b0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cbb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Organisational Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This critical analysis builds on the essay summary already submitted using a similar structure and the same question / statement. Students are expected to have continued to read throughout the internship to find additional literature and to incorporate suggestions in the feedback provided on the summary. Leganto provides a starting point with key texts on both NFP and profit organization but students need to locate specific articles / information that pertain to their host organization / relevant industry. Clear examples from the student's host organization are to provided and linked to the selected organizational components to demonstrate solid reading and reflection on the topics as well as the student's ability to tease out how relevant the literature is to their specific host. Students are encouraged to meet with their host supervisor regularly ( for supervision and to gain feedback on their work) but to also make time to discuss their essay topic so as to gain greater insights into the organization's functioning and processes, history, culture and to learn how to access any relevant documents (mission statements, annual reports etc). At no time does the student name the host organization but refers to the host. Students are to demonstrate an in-depth engagement with the relevant theoretical knowledge and to be able to discuss this within the wider context of Australian and or / overseas where possible. As this is an organizational analysis, students need to show sound skills in locating, evaluating and using relevant information as well as using their initiative and creativity in the manner in which they approach the topic and the conclusions they draw. Combining careful observation with skillful tactful questions to supervisors and other team members will be needed throughout the internship. Students are encouraged to keep regular contact with their Academic Convenor for guidance, discussion of ways to develop this assessment and for tips on further reading.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"72b0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7eb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"feb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d2","links":[]}]},{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"feb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

For most students this is an enjoyable paper to complete. It is made easier by adding some notes each week to a journal on what the student observes, is surprised by, as well as challenging moments or tasks, and highlights that help show that the intern is progressing with skills and / or knowledge of their industry, It is recommended to read an article or two on " internships" early on in the internship (there are many) to gain some insight into the joys and challenges that can be experienced in an internship. It may give students confidence to tackle a challenge early on ( e.g. being given repetitive tasks, or not receiving enough feedback on one's work). Students are expected to cite from two to three articles on internships, from several pieces of organizational literature, share good examples from this internship to support their comments and to include answers to the questions provided on Moodle. A bibliography is to be included with the articles that the student has cited from as well items from the leganto list that are used. Students are encouraged to draw on literature from their University studies. This paper can be structured as the student chooses e.g. into stages of the internship or using the suggested headings on Moodle. It is important that the student can indicate their progress on how they have they engaged with the literature and identify what learning they have achieved in areas such as the challenge of moving from the University setting to the workplace ( especially if it is their first internship), the impact of diversity around them and what ethical and social responsibilities are involved in their industry or area of specialty . Listing key skills and new knowledge gained can be linked to examples from the student's role and tasks undertaken.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,internships,built environment internships,industry experience,work placement,work experience,work integrated learning,placements,professional placement,professional,architecture,planning,interior architecture,landscape architecture,industrial design
contentlets.description: The Professional Placement provides Built Environment students an opportunity to gain targeted professional work experience, and to explore the dynamics, requirements and expectations of a built environment workplace. The placement provides opportunities for students to develop practical knowledge, capabilities and employability skills within a supervised and immersive setting. Students spend 140 hours working with a host organisation on a placement or project basis.
contentlets.title: Professional Placement

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"72b0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cbb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Organisational Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

This critical analysis builds on the essay summary already submitted using a similar structure and the same question / statement. Students are expected to have continued to read throughout the internship to find additional literature and to incorporate suggestions in the feedback provided on the summary. Leganto provides a starting point with key texts on both NFP and profit organization but students need to locate specific articles / information that pertain to their host organization / relevant industry. Clear examples from the student's host organization are to provided and linked to the selected organizational components to demonstrate solid reading and reflection on the topics as well as the student's ability to tease out how relevant the literature is to their specific host. Students are encouraged to meet with their host supervisor regularly ( for supervision and to gain feedback on their work) but to also make time to discuss their essay topic so as to gain greater insights into the organization's functioning and processes, history, culture and to learn how to access any relevant documents (mission statements, annual reports etc). At no time does the student name the host organization but refers to the host. Students are to demonstrate an in-depth engagement with the relevant theoretical knowledge and to be able to discuss this within the wider context of Australian and or / overseas where possible. As this is an organizational analysis, students need to show sound skills in locating, evaluating and using relevant information as well as using their initiative and creativity in the manner in which they approach the topic and the conclusions they draw. Combining careful observation with skillful tactful questions to supervisors and other team members will be needed throughout the internship. Students are encouraged to keep regular contact with their Academic Convenor for guidance, discussion of ways to develop this assessment and for tips on further reading.

\n

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"72b0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7ab0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7eb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"feb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619d2","links":[]}]},{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"feb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619ce","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Reflective Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

For most students this is an enjoyable paper to complete. It is made easier by adding some notes each week to a journal on what the student observes, is surprised by, as well as challenging moments or tasks, and highlights that help show that the intern is progressing with skills and / or knowledge of their industry, It is recommended to read an article or two on " internships" early on in the internship (there are many) to gain some insight into the joys and challenges that can be experienced in an internship. It may give students confidence to tackle a challenge early on ( e.g. being given repetitive tasks, or not receiving enough feedback on one's work). Students are expected to cite from two to three articles on internships, from several pieces of organizational literature, share good examples from this internship to support their comments and to include answers to the questions provided on Moodle. A bibliography is to be included with the articles that the student has cited from as well items from the leganto list that are used. Students are encouraged to draw on literature from their University studies. This paper can be structured as the student chooses e.g. into stages of the internship or using the suggested headings on Moodle. It is important that the student can indicate their progress on how they have they engaged with the literature and identify what learning they have achieved in areas such as the challenge of moving from the University setting to the workplace ( especially if it is their first internship), the impact of diversity around them and what ethical and social responsibilities are involved in their industry or area of specialty . Listing key skills and new knowledge gained can be linked to examples from the student's role and tasks undertaken.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7eb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619cf","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0fb0054cdb80f850fe4b322af49619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Draft Essay Plan Summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Precursor to the organisational essay. 750 to 1000 words. Written feedback within 10 working days. Additional details: The student meets with the Academic Convenor after 2- 3 days of the internship ( or earlier if a Summer internship ) to discuss areas of interest for the topic for this essay summary ( and this topic is maintained for the organisational essay.) The topic is a statement or question that incorporates a few key aspects of organizational theory e.g. the structure, function , culture, leadership, communication, challenges etc that can be closely related to the student's intern tasks. Students can use an approach that incorporates e.g. an organizational perspective, management perspective, knowledge perspective or can look at some organizational models and test out if they are explain how their host organization functions. The structure of this paper will be clarified especially if students have not completed an essay summary before. Although a summary, it is to be written as an academic paper so not dot points. Students develop an argument, and identify how they plan to use relevant texts and articles ( see leganto for our texts and suggested literature) to support this. Suggested ideas are shared by the Convenor, as needed, and support by email and further meetings are provided. Two seminars are offered during the term for peer support, academic guidance and sharing of internship experience. It is crucial , as there are no weekly tutorials , that students start reading as early as they can, to acquaint themselves with aspects of organizational theory that interest them and are relevant to their host. Making links with the reading to one's host can be exciting and insightful. Students must reference this paper with at least five (5) articles in addition to the leganto list which means they need to source five or more relevant articles or chapters on their chosen topic.

contentlets.description: The Professional Placement provides Built Environment students an opportunity to gain targeted professional work experience, and to explore the dynamics, requirements and expectations of a built environment workplace. The placement provides opportunities for students to develop practical knowledge, capabilities and employability skills within a supervised and immersive setting. Students spend 140 hours working with a host organisation on a placement or project basis.
contentlets.title: Professional Placement

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Research: A level of study which involves a student independently researching a specific topic under the guidance of a supervisor and producing a thesis or report. Some research programs involve a coursework component.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Research","value":"rsch"},"code":"BENV7020","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7020 - Research Seminar","description":"

This course helps prepare you to undertake research at the postgraduate degree level and is designed for all UNSW Built Environment postgraduate students undertaking research dissertations. The accent is on research design – the overall visioning and operationalization of your project in ways that respect academic best practice and pragmatic constraints on research (including time and resources).
The course is offered to different cohorts of higher degree research and masters coursework students, all of whom together attend several large group briefings alongside working within their degree programs. Student presentations are complemented by small group sessions which are the responsibility of various degree coordinators. Students are advised to check carefully that the documentation and advice they are considering relates precisely to them.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This compulsory assignment requirement is a draft summary research proposal (1200- 1500 word length) in Microsoft Word format due by Week 5. This proposal will include your responses to all the elements of the research proposal template. This assessment does not require a 'satisfactory' result to pass the course, since it is a formative assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4767edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cf67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6267edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Class tutorial section – presentation
This is a 10-minute maximum compulsory powerpoint presentation of your developed proposal following the major headings of the proposal template.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4767edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cf67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7267edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Developed proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Class tutorial section – developed proposal
The major assignment requirement (compulsory) is a developed research proposal in Microsoft Word format due by Week 11, via Moodle/Turnitin. This assignment will include all the elements of the research proposal template. Overall length of the core text covering headings flagged in sections 4-10 would be 4000-5000 words.

This assignment needs a 'satisfactory' grade to pass the course.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7020","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7020 - Research Seminar","description":"

This course helps prepare you to undertake research at the postgraduate degree level and is designed for all UNSW Built Environment postgraduate students undertaking research dissertations. The accent is on research design – the overall visioning and operationalization of your project in ways that respect academic best practice and pragmatic constraints on research (including time and resources).
The course is offered to different cohorts of higher degree research and masters coursework students, all of whom together attend several large group briefings alongside working within their degree programs. Student presentations are complemented by small group sessions which are the responsibility of various degree coordinators. Students are advised to check carefully that the documentation and advice they are considering relates precisely to them.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0f67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961989","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This compulsory assignment requirement is a draft summary research proposal (1200- 1500 word length) in Microsoft Word format due by Week 5. This proposal will include your responses to all the elements of the research proposal template. This assessment does not require a 'satisfactory' result to pass the course, since it is a formative assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4767edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cf67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6267edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Class tutorial section – presentation
This is a 10-minute maximum compulsory powerpoint presentation of your developed proposal following the major headings of the proposal template.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3a67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4767edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c367edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"cf67edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7267edf7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Developed proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Class tutorial section – developed proposal
The major assignment requirement (compulsory) is a developed research proposal in Microsoft Word format due by Week 11, via Moodle/Turnitin. This assignment will include all the elements of the research proposal template. Overall length of the core text covering headings flagged in sections 4-10 would be 4000-5000 words.

This assignment needs a 'satisfactory' grade to pass the course.

contentlets.description:
This course helps prepare you to undertake research at the postgraduate degree level and is designed for all UNSW Built Environment postgraduate students undertaking research dissertations. The accent is on research design – the overall visioning and operationalization of your project in ways that respect academic best practice and pragmatic constraints on research (including time and resources).
The course is offered to different cohorts of higher degree research and masters coursework students, all of whom together attend several large group briefings alongside working within their degree programs. Student presentations are complemented by small group sessions which are the responsibility of various degree coordinators. Students are advised to check carefully that the documentation and advice they are considering relates precisely to them.

This course will teach the understanding, analysis and generation of high quality architectural and urban communications; writing for the page, for radio and for video about architecture, urbanism and planning. It will look at types and genres of writing and media, at the roles and responsibilities of media, at the relationship between designing, thinking and writing, touching on truth and knowledge (epistemology, ontology), beauty (aesthetics) and the basis of both spatial and textual meaning in our world.


 Is the pen really mightier than the sword? If so, how can it best be wielded in a world teetering on the brink?
