contentlets.description:
This course will teach the understanding, analysis and generation of high quality architectural and urban communications; writing for the page, for radio and for video about architecture, urbanism and planning. It will look at types and genres of writing and media, at the roles and responsibilities of media, at the relationship between designing, thinking and writing, touching on truth and knowledge (epistemology, ontology), beauty (aesthetics) and the basis of both spatial and textual meaning in our world.

 Is the pen really mightier than the sword? If so, how can it best be wielded in a world teetering on the brink?

 The course is constructed around a series of lectures, readings, site visits and research assignments. Assessment is based on both individual and group work.
contentlets.title: Writing the City

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7500","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7500 - Programmable Cities","description":"

Computer programming is becoming an increasingly important skill for people working with urban informatics, big data, and smart cities as it enables professionals to: save time by automating repetitive tasks, accurately document and quickly repeat or modify analytical processes, and ask questions that could not be asked using pre-built software. This course teaches how to automate GIS tasks in the context of urban issues using Python scripting language. This course dedicates time to programming fundamentals so that skills learned can be applied to languages other than Python. Therefore, another benefit from this course is increased ability to adapt to new technologies and programming languages.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"61d5adf3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3 Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 3 - individual assignment (Assessment 35%)
Major coding project for urban applications (Focus on Central Coast Region/NSW)

You will have 4 weeks to complete assignment 3. Support is provided to students by the course instructors along these weeks in two formats: remotely via Moodle; and/or face-to-face via organised group meeting at the University.

Written feedback will be provided individually to students in Moodle for each assignment within two weeks of submission

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"65d5adf3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"15d5adf3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assignment 1 – individual assignment (Assessment 30%)
Demonstrating understanding of principles of programming and basic coding in Python.

This assignment will assess the knowledge and skills you have developed during the first block of classes, focused on fundamentals of programming and introduction to Python. This assignment will help you to consolidate the contents of the first block of classes, and demonstrate understanding of relevant concepts, and also preliminary coding abilities in Python.

Written feedback will be provided for all students on their results via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e9d5adf3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d9d5adf3dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 Individual Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Assignment 2 – individual assignment (Assessment 30%)
Hot spot and time series data analysis with PySAL

This assignment will assess the knowledge and skills you have developed during the second block of classes, focused on programming in Python to assist urban planning and management. Progressing from Assignment 1, Assignment 2 will assess understanding on fundamentals of some relevant data analytical methods and also skills in developing them with python applied to real urban data.

Written feedback will be provided individually to students in Moodle for each assignment within two weeks of submission

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7501","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7501 - Urban Data Visualisation","description":"

It has been said that a picture (or a map) is worth a thousand words. Visual statements can play a critical role in shaping opinions, supporting planning, and helping policy and decision-making in cities. Contemporary cities have grown extraordinarily complex and can be described and analysed through an increasing variety of social, economic and environmental data in different dimensions. New 3D tools have been created to cope with the large availability of urban data and models, make sense of it and report it to varied audiences in a meaningful and appealing way. 3D innovative interactive and digital maps are changing city design and planning by providing more elaborated analysis and simulations, and convincing impressions. Therefore, building capacity on what kind of data structures, system architectures and software tools are needed is an asset for anybody working in the field of urban planning and management. Visualisation is a critical component of modelling, analysing and understanding the built environment and this course will arm the students with the theory and techniques to harness the power of 3D visualisation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"413cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3D modelling and visualization","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The first assessment is intended to test the ability of the student to select a desktop visualization environment with respect to an application and available data as a well as the skills to integrate data for synthesized visualizations.

   

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"053cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"413cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7c3c74f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Web-based visualization","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The second assessment focusses on theoretical and practical knowledge of the student to work with web-based environments. The students have to be able to analyse and decide which approaches for 3D modelling are appropriate for a specific urban visualization requirement

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"053cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"413cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7c3c74f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Game engine project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

The third assessment refers to the ability of the student to create visualization and interaction environment suitable for solving urban planning or urban analysis tasks.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"053cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d3cb4f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b43c74f7dbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BENV7501.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

The goal of this class is to introduce geodesign principles to students. Geodesign is a design and planning method which tightly couples the creation of design, landscape and city planning with simulations informed by geographic contexts, systems thinking and digital technology (adapted from - Flaxman 2012). The objective of this course is to introduce the fundamental theory, concepts, and frameworks of geodesign put forward by Dr. Carl Steinitz (Steinitz 2012). Students will become familiar with the geodesign process by reviewing case studies including specific case study applications.

Feedback: verbal feedback, written feedback, and rubric

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7503","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7503 - Geocomputation","description":"

This course will provide students the skills to undertake sophisticated spatial (statistical) analysis and simulation. GeoComputation is in part the continuing development and application of analytical statistics that can be applied to clustering, search and measures of association over space and through time. The course will provide students with the theoretical and mathematical background behind numerous spatial analytical techniques, and also to select and integrate these methods in a way that it is appropriate for the problems addressed and the data available. Ultimately, the course will enhance the intellectual and methodological capacity of students in the domain of urban problem-solving. The course will use varied analytical environments, including software and R programming.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f11db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619ba","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Lab assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Lab assignments are designed to monitor students' comprehension of the weekly tutorial content and provide ongoing feedback to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f51db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fd1db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b51db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

In this group assignment, students demonstrate their understanding of the real-world problems, choose a problem to solve, evaluate methods and select the best method to solve the problem. These all can be done through research and implementation of the geocomputation skills that they have learnt in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f11db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fd1db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f51db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Code review","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students learn how to find and develop geocomputational codes to support the planning and development of a specific urban project. Students develop skills of independent research and critical thinking as they assess the best available code; they also apply skills learned in the weekly tutorials to test and develop the code.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f11db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fd1db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619bd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fd1db8b8dbede01055a93324f39619c3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BENV7503.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7504","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7504 - Digital Cities","description":"

This course explores the breadth of data available to urban policymakers, using recently completed and indeed 'live' projects being undertaken within City Futures Research Centre and Built Environment more widely. With the Faculty providing a principal hub in the Australian Urban Research Infrastructure Network (AURIN), students will have access to innovative, nationwide spatial datasets: Australian cities and Sydney in particular will be our laboratory, but international perspectives will be drawn upon. Integral to exploring the application of these data and the techniques to do so, students will be encouraged to critically engage with the politics and power embedded in the emergence of the ‘Smart City’ and the complexity associated with data access , knowledge production and dissemination.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"df62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961977","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Mid Term Quiz 20% - Research Question and Initial Design Strategies (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment will test the students’ knowledge on Geodesign in relation to the prescribed reading set “A Framework for Geodesign” by Carl Steintiz 2012. This will include questions pertaining to the history of Geodesign, the Geodesign methodology and scoping out a Geodesign process. Students will need to answer approximately 30 multiple choice questions.

Assessment type: Online multiple-choice quiz via Moodle (Individual)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8762d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 3 –Design Workshop Presentation (Group) – 25%","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This assessment is based on students’ participation and group work in an intensive 2-day Geodesign real world exercise. Here they undergo a workshop focused on the sustainable regional growth of the Central Coast Region. Students will develop a series of projects, policies and future scenarios for the region then negotiate an agreed upon scenario for the region. Students will work in small groups (4-5 people) and present the results of their background research, projects, policies and scenarios across the two days. This is an opportunity to showcase what have individuals learnt on the course as well as learn from the instructors and peers.

Assessment type: Class presentation (group)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8762d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d362d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7662d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 4 – Discussion Board Activities (Individual) - 20%","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be given a series of short activities across Weeks 1-9. In these activities students will need to read the prescribed chapters from the Geodesign text and other reading materials assigned each week. Students are required to post comments on the group discussion board. Others’ posts are available once student has submitted their own work.  Responses are expected to be between 200-600 words each.

Assessment type: Short postings – via Moodle (Individual)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0f62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8762d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d362d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 1: Progressive Geodesign Assignment (Individual) - 35%","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

This assignment is a progressive online assignment comprising of seven parts undertaken across Weeks 1-8. These include Part 1: Reflection on the Geodesign Workshop (individual), Part 2: Scoping a Geodesign Project Worksheet (Individual), Part 3: Create a Geodesign Map (Individual), Part 4: Geodesign Online Group (Group Discussion / Individual Report), Part 5: Geodesign Group Negotiation exercise (Group Discussion / Individual Report), Part 6: Geodesign Tools & Techniques (Individual), Part 7: Geodesign Workshop Proposal (Individual).

Students download a worksheet for each of these assignments which comprise of a short overview, a set of instructions and a problem overview. They then complete the necessary tasks. Group exercises are supported via a Moodle Group Forum. While the two assignments include discussions as a group, assessment is comprised of individual reflections.

Assessment type: Multiple digital submissions (.docx/.pdf) onto Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4b62d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f262d173dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BENV7504.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7550","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7550 - Smart Cities and Urban Informatics Major Project","description":"

The Smart Cities and Urban Informatics Project represents the culmination of studies in the Smart Cities and Urban Informatics. Students will work closely with the Director of the Program to develop a proposal. Projects which tap into current ‘live’ projects, building upon existing partnerships internationally through the PLuS Alliance and with industry and government organisations including Department of Planning and Environment, the Greater Sydney Commission, Urban Growth, Sydney Water, and the Department of Finance, Services and Innovation, along with partnerships with local councils including the City of Sydney, Randwick City Council and Parramatta., will be encouraged. This might take the form of a discrete element or task within its ongoing strategic development or implementation, or a more general critical analysis of the Smart City agenda. The major project report can take the form of a research thesis or a practice-oriented report. Each student will be assigned a supervisor, and it is expected that many students will also benefit from engagement with industry partners. The final thesis/report will be 10-12,000 words long. Where partners have been directly involved, students will be encouraged to provide a short debrief to the relevant organisations. The production of the thesis will explore and provide new insights into one or more of the challenges facing cities through the integration of research and/or practical insight.

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7712","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7712 - Healthy Built Environments","description":"

Healthy Built Environments is a postgraduate elective that focuses on the role of the built environment in supporting healthy behaviours that reduce major risk factors for chronic diseases across the life course for diverse communities. The course examines the ways in which health and built environment professionals are collaboratively addressing the epidemic of chronic disease associated with sedentary and socially isolated urban living. Current research, legislative and policy frameworks, together with best practice from Australia and abroad, are presented and critically evaluated. The challenges of inter-disciplinary research, policy development and implementation are considered. This course is specifically designed for students undertaking post graduate studies in built environment and health. Classes involve a mixture of lectures, participant discussion and critical review, hands-on experience with different tools, field trip and group presentation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b14f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Healthy Built Environments (Group Presentation)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

In mixed disciplinary groups you will prepare a PowerPoint presentation for an interested, intelligent but non expert audience on a contemporary aspect of healthy built environments anywhere in the world.  Selection of topics will be discussed in class and must be approved by the course convenor.  Latest research evidence is to be included, as is plain English text for the commentary and engaging illustrations. The final presentation will be given to everyone on Day 5 of the course, making this a learning experience for us all.

Group assessment

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"254f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3d4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"614f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"794f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ad4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"154f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment 2: Open Space Project (Individual)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

You will undertake a research and reflective/experiential exercise in a green open space area of your choice.  This will require synthesis of key literature as well as immersion in the chosen site, reporting (in text and images) on a set of reflections about its qualities and your experience. 

Individual assessment

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"254f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3d4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a14f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ad4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO8","cl_id":"b54f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5d4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961984","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Field trip quiz – this is a short quiz about the places observed on our field trip

Individual assessment

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"254f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"614f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"fd4f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d94f9db3db7d1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: My Day","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Short personal reflections as follows:

 

My day on a plate – record a typical day’s eating; can this be healthier; more sociable?

 

Social interaction and place making – reflect on your observations and interactions within a public square or street – does this connect you with others?  How?  Challenges?

Individual assessment

An introduction to Geographical Information Systems (GIS) and their applications in urban studies, planning, public management, public health, environment planning, and business contexts. A solid understanding of fundamental concepts, principles, and functions of GIS, and of types of spatial data, their entry, analysis and display into a GIS. Overview of technical and institutional issues in GIS development. Teaching will involve lectures and computer laboratories.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"af986219db017c10fe4b322af4961919","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Lab assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Brief scenario
Imagine you are the GIS analyst of the city of Inner West, you have been requested to visualize and analyse
raw cycling data (collected by another survey department in the city council) along the Greenway
https://www.greenway.org.au/. You will need to use Google Earth or other tools to visualize the provided
data.

The submissions include:
- Project report, between 1,300- 1,500 words
- Zip file that contain all the layers and reference files.

The learning, feedback and assessments that occur within classes are invaluable to student progress.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"23986219db017c10fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b986219db017c10fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f986219db017c10fe4b322af496191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"67986219db017c10fe4b322af496191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":null,"learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"23986219db017c10fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2b986219db017c10fe4b322af496191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2b986219db017c10fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2f986219db017c10fe4b322af496191b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7db92e19db017c10fe4b322af4961989","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Brief scenario
Based on your previous assignment, you are now requested to work in groups of 3 to 4 students. Each group
will create a different design layout in the nominated precinct. You will explore different land use, different
densification levels, suggest more green space or walking pathways etc. Create a vision of how this precinct
may look like after the redevelopment take place. Use digitizing and GIS techniques you have learned in this
course you will then export your GIS data and present it in a cartographical correct and visually engaging map story. Some examples can be found here: https://storymaps.arcgis.com/en/ or https://mapme.com/stories/ and
https://mapstory.org/ or here https://cityfutures.be.unsw.edu.au/cityviz/

The submissions include:
- Project report, between 1,300- 1,500 words max
- Zip file that contain all the GIS layers and reference files; and
- Link to the created Story Map and presentation videos.

This project consists of a group assignment worth 30% of the course and an individual presentation worth 10% of the overall marks in the course.   

The learning, feedback and assessments that occur within classes are invaluable to student progress.

In this course you will learn the technical and legal aspects involved in the successful completion of  a comprehensive set of tender and construction documents for major buildings. You will use  architectural documentation techniques, primarily Building Information Modelling (BIM) to prepare and assess working drawings, including design details, specifications and schedules. You will develop knowledge of the relevant Australian Standards and Building Codes and their application to the design and construction of a major building.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"58f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2 – Collaborative Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

(25% Group work, 5% Collaboration journal – Self-evaluation)

A group of students will develop a building complex integrating individual building designs. A complete set of documents, generated from a central BIM model, will be reviewed by the tutor and student peers. Students will collaborate on the central model and its documentation from general arrangement plans to details and schedules.

25% of the mark will be given to the group documentation and the other 5% determined by self-evaluation (collaboration journal).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"18f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9cf8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af4961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 – Individual Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Assignment 1 – Individual Documentation

Students will develop the BIM model of a building and generate a typical set of documents with reference to the relevant Australian Standards.

Individual Documentation will be reviewed each week in class by the tutor and student peers. Formal feedback on the assessment tasks will be a review set of the submission with comments by the tutor which highlight the critique of the work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"18f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"60f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496192e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"BIM Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Create a BIM report to manage the design information of a major building, involving a BIM brief, BIM management plan and level of development (LOD).

Students will develop this BIM documentation to define the key elements of a project such as client’s requirements, project-specific circumstances, and appropriate LOD.

Students will receive feedback for their work in two ways: 1. Verbal feedback weekly during the tutorials (assignment development) 2. Written feedback on their submitted assignments (including rubrics and comments on the work itself).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"18f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9cf8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af496191e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a0f8a4f1db7f6050fe4b322af4961928","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BENV7800.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This studio is undertaken in the belief that a knowledge and understanding of materials, structure and construction greatly enhances the architectural process. The brief will generally call for the development of a series of comprehensively detailed timber structures to fit within an environmentally sensitive zone. The project will focus on the conception and structural resolution of a clear-span timber public building and associated works constructed in timber.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c4aa6533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1. Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Group Presentation:   Working in groups of 3, research, present and report on one of the following:

  • The natural forest resource in NSW.  
  • Engineered products and developments.  
  • Joints, Junctions and fixings.
  • Longevity: issues of durability, hazard, fire, etc. 
","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"679a6533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"3. Final design Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Interim design submission: Class presentation;   sketches and models to clearly explain the basics of your design proposal.  

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"679a6533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961927","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"2. Interim design submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Interim design submission: Class presentation;   sketches and models to clearly explain the basics of your design proposal.  

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f9a6533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961922","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"4. Individual Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Individual Report:  an A4 hardcopy document which will present the case to your clients and their specialist advisors.    The report is to include the following:

  • A timber assessment listing all timbers used in the design, estimated volumes of each species, ‘rarity’ value, durability and a “wood-miles” estimate.
  • An analysis of a main primary structural system showing load calculations and demonstrating a rationale for your estimate of the member size.
  • A commentary on the sustainability of the building fabric.
  • A description of the proposed construction process and the measures you envisage to minimise disturbance to the region.
","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f9a6533dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/BENV7806.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7811","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7811 - Urban Renewal","description":"

This course will introduce students to key concepts concerned with urban spatial dynamics; the drivers and processes of urban spatial restructuring; and the potential roles and forms of state intervention in influencing such restructuring. Students will become familiar with the evolution of official thinking on renewing Australia’s cities to the present day; its changing goals, terminology and financing. They will also gain an appreciation of the range of stakeholders with interests in urban renewal, and of their contrasting roles and perspectives. Framing themes running through the course will include system governance and the distributional consequences of urban restructuring. While its coverage of urban renewal practice will have a particular focus on Sydney, the course will also acknowledge and explain respects in which urban processes and policy approaches have differed in other Australian capital cities. Additionally, it will contain an international comparative dimension especially to help explain the emergence of policy thinking in Europe and North America which has often come to have an influence here in Australia.

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"BENV7812","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7812 - Critical Spatial Thinkers","description":"

Who has shaped critical debate within the interdisciplinary context of built environment theory? What are the key texts which help define and act as pivotal references within those debates? Each discipline has its crucial influences, and it is often at the interface across those disciplinary divides that the most powerful exchanges, arguments and theoretical innovation have been fostered. Pivotal to our field is a capacity to think and engage spatially. We privilege space in our view of the world, and as a basis for understanding the complexities which shape processes and societal interactions within built environment contexts. This course challenges students to critically engage with key spatial thinkers and their works, for example David Harvey, Henri Lefebvre and Manual Castells, and share their perspectives on how this work infuses the way we understand, engage with, practice in, and seek to change, the world around us. Each week, a group of students will report on and lead discussion focusing on their selected thinker. Students will be expected to read extensively and strong emphasis will be placed on students’ participation in these discussions. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fde474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961949","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major assignment of critical spatial thinker","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will select one of the spatial thinkers whose work is considered in this course and will critically engage with the key arguments, or a particular aspect of the chosen thinker’s works, for their final written assignment. Students are free to select the same thinker who provided the focus for their seminar or chose an alternative (3500 words).


Written feedback will be provided by the lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b1e474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"25e474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical issues diary","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will maintain a reflective diary drawing together thoughts from readings as well as observations from the seminar discussion. Over the semester, the aim is to encourage students to be exposed to a breadth of ideas and debates – some will be more applicable and identifiably relevant to their particular interests (1500 words).


Students will be provided with written feedback from the lecturer.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fde474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961936","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59e474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961910","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students are expected to actively engage each week in the seminars, demonstrating that they have prepared for class through reading and come willing to share their views and perspectives.


Peer discussion and critique.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b1e474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a1e474f3dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group work: seminar lead","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will be assigned a key spatial thinker. They will work as a group to prepare an introductory think-piece to set up the seminar and then led discussion. This introduction will last for approximately 45 minutes.


Peer discussion and critique. Feedback will be provided by the lecturer.

contentlets.keywords: built environment,planning theory,critical urban theory,marxist urban theory,urban sociology,spatial thinking
contentlets.description: Who has shaped critical debate within the interdisciplinary context of built environment theory? What are the key texts which help define and act as pivotal references within those debates? Each discipline has its crucial influences, and it is often at the interface across those disciplinary divides that the most powerful exchanges, arguments and theoretical innovation have been fostered. Pivotal to our field is a capacity to think and engage spatially. We privilege space in our view of the world, and as a basis for understanding the complexities which shape processes and societal interactions within built environment contexts. This course challenges students to critically engage with key spatial thinkers and their works, for example David Harvey, Henri Lefebvre and Manual Castells, and share their perspectives on how this work infuses the way we understand, engage with, practice in, and seek to change, the world around us. Each week, a group of students will report on and lead discussion focusing on their selected thinker. Students will be expected to read extensively and strong emphasis will be placed on students’ participation in these discussions.
contentlets.title: Critical Spatial Thinkers

This elective will focus on one of architectures primary modes of investigation; the model. As a critical part of the design process the model expresses ideas and concepts in three dimensions with concern for materials, lighting, space and, nowadays, interactivity; in other words the model literally presents all of the components of a finished architecture. Traditionally architectural models have been hand-made which both reflected the building process of the time and a cultural longing by architects to be more directly involved in the production of their work (many architects design products, especially furniture, for the same reason). But for some time now architecture has been tending towards the assembly of factory made components; and, as can be seen across the world, factories tend towards automated machine-made production. It’s worthwhile to point out at this stage that beautiful things are created in factories. Porsche, Honda, Apple, Prada and Boeing (to name a few) all use factories to create amazingly sophisticated products; most for a fraction of the cost of the average architect designed building.   


If architectural models should reflect both the finished architecture and its mode of production they will need to employ automated processes such as digital modelling, laser cutting, CNC milling and rapid prototyping. However, this elective isn’t dogmatic; several hand-made processes will also be employed (hot-wire cutting blue foam, casting, sheet metal folding). In this elective students will be trained to use and have direct access to all of these machines.


In this elective students will select 3 from the number of techniques on offer to fabricate components that have precedents in architecture relating to the students design studio. Following online courses students will be expected to enroll in practical sessions. Successfully completing these courses will be mandatory.


Further assessment will be based on the physical models themselves, representations of them and critical reflection on the process and outcomes.

Brief: Choose 3 Architectural precedents and use the project matrix below to articulate your plan to realize 3 fabrications.

Submitted in two stages; stage one is a draft submitted in week two (must submit on time to pass the course), stage two is the refined matrix which is assessed in week eight. This assessment will demonstrate theory development, form comprehension and project management;

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5b87253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b87253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Fabrications","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Brief: Create three physical fabrications demonstrating mastery of the nominated concepts, techniques and materials.
Assessment Criteria (weighting in brackets):
Quality of Fabrication (30%): are the models well made?
Accuracy (20%): do the models accurately reflect the geometry of their selected element?
Ambition (30%): are the models conceptually as well as technically ambitious?
Range (20%): do the models demonstrate a good range of scales/materials/ techniques?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2387253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9787253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d387253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"ef87253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4b87253bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Documentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Brief: Document in still and moving images both the process of fabrication and assembly as well as the completed outcomes.
Assessment Criteria (weighting in brackets):
Thorough (40%): is the documentation comprehensive?
Imaginative (30%): is the documentation imaginative?
Repeatable (30%): would the documentation facilitate repeatability?

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BENV7814 - Asian Urbanism Laboratory","description":"

This intensive interdisciplinary studio is open to architecture, landscape, interior, urban design and city planning students. Each year, the studio will take place in different cities in South, Southeast and East Asia and address a variety of themes including heritage, livability, re-development, regeneration, social justice and sustainability.


 Each city will offer a particular set of research, analysis and design challenges that demands full participation from the students. Based on the specific project site, students will be required to examine governmental policies, social and cultural factors, and the urban fabric to diagnose the site’s strengths and weaknesses and propose design interventions to improve the targeted built environment.

contentlets.description:
This intensive interdisciplinary studio is open to architecture, landscape, interior, urban design and city planning students. Each year, the studio will take place in different cities in South, Southeast and East Asia and address a variety of themes including heritage, livability, re-development, regeneration, social justice and sustainability.

 Each city will offer a particular set of research, analysis and design challenges that demands full participation from the students. Based on the specific project site, students will be required to examine governmental policies, social and cultural factors, and the urban fabric to diagnose the site’s strengths and weaknesses and propose design interventions to improve the targeted built environment.
